{{Infobox book | name = Encyclopaedia Beliana | image = Encyclopaedia Beliana 1.JPG | alt = Encyclopaedia Beliana volumes 1 – 5 | image_size = 200px | caption = ''Encyclopaedia Beliana'' volumes 1 – 5 | author = | illustrator = | country = Slovakia | language = [[Slovak language|Slovak]] | subject = General | genre = [[Reference work|Reference]] encyclopaedia | publisher = [[Slovak Academy of Sciences]]
[http://www.encyclopaedia.sk Official site] | published = | release_date = 1999 – present | media_type = 12+ volumes, hardbound | pages = | awards = | isbn = | wikisource = }} '''''Encyclopaedia Beliana''''' is a [[Slovakia|Slovak]] [[encyclopedia]]. When completed, it will contain ca. 150,000 headwords in twelve illustrated volumes, as well as supplements. ''Beliana'' is prepared by the [[Slovak Academy of Sciences]]. Its name, ''Beliana'', is derived from [[Matej Bel]], 18th century [[Slovaks|Slovak]] writer and historian.{{cite web | url =http://www.encyclopaedia.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=8:projekt-encyclopaedia-beliana&catid=6:bel-matej&Itemid=9 | title =Projekt Encyclopaedia Beliana | language =Slovak | last = | first = | date = | website =www.encyclopaedia.sk | publisher =Slovak Academy of Sciences | accessdate =2014-04-28 }} As of 2014, seven volumes were published. == Coverage == ''Encyclopaedia Beliana'' is a universal encyclopedia with its contents divided into three parts: the first on [[natural science]]s, the second on spiritual [[culture]] and the third on [[technology]]. == Volumes == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Volume ! Year of publication ! ISBN |- | 1. A - Belk | 1999 | {{ISBN|80-224-0554-X}} |- | 2. Bell - Czy | 2001 | {{ISBN|80-224-0671-6}} |- | 3. Č - {{not a typo|Eg}} | 2003 | {{ISBN|80-224-0761-5}} |- | 4. Eh - Gala | 2005 | {{ISBN|80-224-0847-6}} |- | 5. Galb - Hir | 2008 | {{ISBN|978-80-224-0982-7}} |- | 6. His - Im | 2010 | {{ISBN|978-80-970350-0-6}} |- | 7. In - Kalg |2013 | {{ISBN|978-80-970350-1-3}} |- | 8. Kalh - Kokp |2016 |{{ISBN|978-80-970350-2-0}} |} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.encyclopaedia.sk Official site of the ''Encyclopaedia Beliana''] [[Category:Slovak encyclopedias]] [[Category:20th-century encyclopedias]] [[Category:21st-century encyclopedias]] {{slovakia-stub}} {{encyclopedia-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox book | name = | image = Encyclopedia of Chicago cover.jpg |alt=book cover bearing the title The Encyclopedia of Chicago | caption = ''Encyclopedia of Chicago'' (2004)
[http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/ official website] | author = James R. Grossman, Ann Durkin Keating, and Janice L. Reiff (all editors) | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[History of Chicago]] | genre = [[Reference work|Reference]] [[encyclopedia]] | publisher = [[University of Chicago Press]] | release_date = October 15, 2004 (print)
May 11, 2005 (online) | media_type = [[hardbound]]/[[internet]] | isbn = 0-226-31015-9 | dewey= 977.3/11/003 22 | congress= F548.3 .E53 2004 | oclc = 54454572 | pages = 1117{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/ow/5c397adae8b174aaa19afeb4da09e526.html|title=The encyclopedia of Chicago|accessdate=September 24, 2009|publisher=[[WorldCat]]}} }} '''''The Encyclopedia of Chicago''''' is an historical [[reference work]] covering [[Chicago]] and the entire [[Chicago metropolitan area]] published by the [[University of Chicago Press]]. Released in October 2004, the work is the result of a ten-year collaboration between the [[Newberry Library]] and the [[Chicago Historical Society]]. It exists in both a [[hardcover]] print edition and an online format, known as the '''''Electronic Encyclopedia of Chicago'''''.{{cite web|url=http://www.newberry.org/scholl/encyclopedia.html |title=The Encyclopedia of Chicago |accessdate=September 24, 2009 |publisher=[[Newberry Library]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206164225/http://www.newberry.org/scholl/encyclopedia.html |archivedate=December 6, 2008 }} The print edition is 1117 pages and includes 1400 entries, 2000 biographical sketches, 250 significant business enterprise descriptions, and hundreds of maps. Initially, the internet edition included 1766 entries, 1000 more images and sources. The concept was fueled by other regional encyclopedias that had met with commercial success in 1980s and 1990s. Eventually, the vision to create the book found initial financing from the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]]. The book was well received and became a [[bestseller]] during the 2004 Christmas season following its October 2004 release. The following May the ''Electronic Encyclopedia of Chicago'' was released. [[Northwestern University]] joined the Newberry Library/Chicago Historical Society collaboration to publish the internet edition. The internet edition was the second of its kind for a U.S. city. ==Details== Individual entries were compiled by [[historian]]s, [[graduate assistant]]s and [[author]]s. Most contributors were [[professor]]s. About 600 people contributed entries at a rate of $.10/per word. The contributors consulted reliable [[secondary source]]s, such as [[newspaper]]s, to compile historical accounts.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0FBFAFA171559E8D&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=History sleuths dig up suburbs' hidden pasts|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=June 29, 2003|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Vogt, Amanda|page=1, Metro section}} The book was edited by James R. Grossman, Ann Durkin Keating, and Janice L. Reiff. At the time, Grossman was the vice president for research and education at the Newberry Library and visiting professor of history at the [[University of Chicago]]. Keating was a professor of history at [[North Central College]]. Reiff was an associate professor of history at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]].{{cite web|url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/books/grossman/about.html|title=The Encyclopedia of Chicago|accessdate=September 24, 2009|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]}} Unlike resource compilation efforts for the cities that inspired this encyclopedia, the work was not bounded by the [[city limits]]. Instead, every suburb was provided an entry, as were each of Chicago's 77 official [[Community areas of Chicago|community areas]]. Entries ranged from 50 to 4000 words long.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CSTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB42308EA5C72A8&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Tome chronicles Chicago from stockyards to pizza|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=May 26, 1997|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|author=Ritter, Jim|page=47, News section}} Eventually, the coverage of the subject matter expanded to include Southwest [[Michigan]] and [[Northwest Indiana]].{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CSTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB42469817312CC&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Writing a perfect history of Chicago|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=March 9, 2000|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|author=Steinberg, Neil|page=40, Section 2}} Newberry Library describes the work as "one of the most significant historical projects undertaken in the last twenty years". ==History== Inspired by encyclopedia compilation efforts of cities such as New York City, Indianapolis and Cleveland, Keating approached the Newberry Library in 1991 to strategize on how to best to study and teach Chicago history. Eventually she and Grossman agreed to prepare a funding request from the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] (NEH). Their initial proposal was declined, but after working with Grossman to refine the specifics of their proposal, the NEH accepted their idea.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB426A534FBBE7C&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=The Way We Were, In One Million Words|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=April 2, 1995|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Christiansen, Richard|page=2, Arts section}} The book venture was originally announced in 1994 as a project funded by a NEH [[US$]]200,000 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|200000|1994|r=0}}}} today) grant.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB4263BB73D65EB&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Vast History Project May Turn CD-ROM Into CD-Chicago|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=November 25, 1994|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Pridmore, Jay|page=30}} The grant also included a $300,000 [[challenge grant]] to be met by Newberry Library for the first three years of work. The original plan was to publish a hardcover book by 2001 and then to follow with what at the time was referred to vaguely as "hypermedia" in reference to possible internet and [[CD-ROM]] auxiliary products. After Grossman and Keating obtained the initial grant, Reiff, a computer technology expert, and encyclopedia veteran Carol J. Summerfield all became part of the team. The editors sought the advice of Chicago-area [[librarians]] who were organized into focus groups to determine the proper components for the planned publication. The editors also organized into task forces of experts in dozens of specialized fields. Early on they sought the expertise of [[University of Chicago]] [[cartographer]] Michael P. Conzen, who helped develop 56 original maps. Conzen is credited as the cartographic editor. By 1997, the text had taken shape and the plan was that the average biographical entry would be 150 words. The longest biographical entries, about 450 words, were written for former [[Chicago Mayor]]s [[Harold Washington]] and [[Richard J. Daley]]. Neither [[Richard M. Daley]] nor [[Michael Jordan]] had entries because only notable deceased persons were included. By 1998, the editors had settled on the table of contents and begun the job of assigning, editing, fact-checking and re-editing the hundreds of entries, some of them as long as 4000 words. By March 2000, 1100 of the targeted 1400 entries were completed. Also, the growth of the internet had clarified the vision of an online version of the print edition. In 2000, the final volume was expected to be 1300 pages set for release in fall 2002. The internet version was expected the following year. By June 2001, nearly 1300 of the entries had been submitted and a third had been edited and reviewed for accuracy. The effort had become a $2.5 million effort and was aspiring towards the success of earlier encyclopedic efforts projecting a fall 2003 publication of a 1.3-million-word 1300-page edition. At this time, the final electronic form available through the Chicago Historical Society had been conceptualized. ==Public release== By 2001, two editions of ''The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History'' (1987) had sold 24,000 copies; ''The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis'' (1994) had sold 9000 copies and ''[[The Encyclopedia of New York City]]'' (1995) had sold 70,000 (50,000 in its first year). Hardcover versions of these works had sold for $59.95 and up. The commercial success of these other regional encyclopedias made it clear that there is a market for such products.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0ECF19E3DB5844E5&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=The Chicago story - Book to show racial, ethnic, economic diversity of area |accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=June 13, 2001|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Reardon, Patrick T.|page=3, Tempo section}} Several university presses released regional encyclopedic publications in 2004. In April, [[Rutgers University Press]] published ''[[The Encyclopedia of New Jersey]]''. In September, the [[University of Nebraska Press]] published ''Encyclopedia of the Great Plains''. In October, the University of Chicago Press released ''The Encyclopedia of Chicago''. Additionally, [[Yale University Press]] was scheduled to publish both ''Encyclopedia of New England'' and the second edition of ''The Encyclopedia of New York City''.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:EQUB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=105BEC236D99576A&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=UPs Get Hip to Encyclopedias|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 11, 2004|work=Executive Quote and Information Service | first=Raya | last=Kuzyk}} Using [[press release]]s from the [[Copley News Service]],{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:COPB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=122F56A824272850&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Windy City's history compressed into new volume|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 4, 2004|work=[[Copley News Service]]|author=Ramsey, Mike}}{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:COPB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=122F56A82493CCD0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Book gives nod, briefly o downstate|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 4, 2004|work=[[Copley News Service]]|author=Ramsey, Mike}} the book was widely publicized throughout the state of [[Illinois]],{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:SJRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=105CFE4956BA1225&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Downstate Illinois gets few mentions in encyclopedia|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 4, 2004|work=[[The State Journal-Register]]|page=4, News section|author=Ramsey, Mike}}{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:PJSB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1059C45DE68D104C&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=New book bursts with tales of Chicago's colorful past - Encyclopedia profiles politics, sports, liquor, crime and much more|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 4, 2004|work=[[Peoria Journal Star]]|page=B2, City section|author=Ramsey, Mike}} and it was even reviewed by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WSAB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=105B28B1B681AB43&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Review/Books|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 8, 2004|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|page=W8 | first=Joseph | last=Epstein}} When first published in 2004, the book was on the ''[[USA Today]]'' recommended Christmas gifts list.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:USTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=106BDBF66114611F&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Zero in on the one book that will mean the most|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=December 2, 2004|work=[[USA Today]]|author=Minzesheimer, Bob|page=5D}} That year it was at the top of the Chicago area [[bestseller]] lists at bookstores during the [[Christmas]] holiday season.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1073A85799C59453&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=From The Precincts. Local booksellers tell us what Chicago is buying.|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=December 26, 2004|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=6, Books section}}{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=107159CE909E46DB&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=From The Precincts. Local booksellers tell us what Chicago is buying.|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=December 19, 2004|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=6, Books section}} Major funding for the $65 list price four-color print version of the publication, which cost $1.7 million in the end, was provided by the NEH, the [[MacArthur Foundation]], the City of Chicago and the State of Illinois. ===Electronic edition=== At the time of the print release, the online version, known as the ''Electronic Encyclopedia of Chicago'', was being developed to include additional features, which relied on [[hyperlink]]s, that were not available in the print edition. At the time, it was expected to be released by the Chicago Historical Society in April 2005. On May 11, the Electronic edition, which cost nearly $1 million to create and is continuously available for free to the public, was released. It included hundreds of additional entries (bringing the total to 1766), more than 1000 additional images, video of historic figures and events, and extensive primary source material. The online version includes 1000 more sources than the print edition.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10A077528727044A&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=City's colorful history enters the cyber age - Chicago encyclopedia to be offered online |accessdate=September 25, 2009|date=May 11, 2005|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=2, Metro section|author=McCarthy, Brendan}} The Web site includes many tables and maps that date to the 19th Century. [[Northwestern University]] media specialists developed the Web architecture for the electronic version.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CSTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10A2638D0E32C904&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Vast Encyclopedia of Chicago goes on the Web // The price is right: free -- and online version has nifty new features|accessdate=September 25, 2009|date=May 11, 2005|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|page=10, News section|author=McNamee, Tom}} The electronic edition made Chicago the second major U.S. city (following Cleveland) with an extensive Internet encyclopedia dedicated to its history and its release was covered by newspapers throughout the [[Midwest]].{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:GPTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10A7225A7545B410&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Chicago city history will be online, free|accessdate=September 25, 2009|date=May 19, 2005|work=[[Post-Tribune]]|page=A10, National section}}{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:DTHB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10A48274544AF829&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=New Chicago encyclopedia offers free online edition - It is 2nd major city to offer historical information over the Internet|accessdate=September 25, 2009|date=May 23, 2005|work=[[Telegraph Herald]]|page=d2}} The extra features of the online edition would have required 10,000 pages to produce in print-edition format. Initially, the online edition was a static version, but updates and adjustments were planned. ==Critical review== ''USA Today''' referred to it as a good [[coffee table book]]. ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' journalist Rick Kogan describes this as a massive undertaking with the natural foibles of the human element in it selections and accuracy, and by nature of its attempt to serve as a historical compilation an immediately dated product due to the dynamic nature of the city. However, he feels it is sure to amaze its audience. A ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' reviewer describes it as a scholarly product that is "easily the most comprehensive reference book on the Chicago region ever published". ''[[The State Journal-Register]]'', the [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]], Illinois newspaper, reviewers complain that downstate cities and regions are neglected in the book. A ''[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]'' review describes it as a book accurately "billed as the city's most definitive historical reference book". The ''[[Peoria Journal Star]]'' notes that although there are complaints about omissions and underserved topics, the online version should quell the demands for further knowledge. The online version was noted for its "large number of tables and maps that date to the 19th Century" by the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. [[Dubuque, Iowa|Dubuque]], Iowa's ''[[Telegraph Herald]]'' newspaper and [[Indiana]]'s ''[[Post-Tribune]]'' referenced an [[Associated Press]] press release that described the online version as a compilation assembled "with more than Chicagoans in mind". The ''Chicago Tribune'' described the online version as an extension of "the most comprehensive reference book on the Chicago region ever published" that is unlimited by physical bounds. ''[[Journal of American History]]'' along with the website History Matters: The U.S. Survey Course on the Web published a review by [[University of Southern California]] professor Philip J. Ethington that spoke glowingly about both versions of the encyclopedia describing it as "one of the finest collective works (with 633 listed authors) of North American historical scholarship of our era". They praised it for its breadth and coherence. The online version was noted for its meticulous [[hyperlink]]ing. The online review was cursory in the sense that it did not realize the expansion of the online version. However, the review notes that the online version provides "powerful and substantive" interactive resources that are not possible in the print edition. The review is especially respectful of the cartographic contributions, which it describes in detail. It dismisses the alphabetical structure of the online version as an unnecessary complication. The review also complains about biographical omissions that necessitate extensive navigation to related articles. The review felt some of the online foibles left open the possibility that the production might get overshadowed by future ventures that leverage the electronic possibilities more fully.{{cite journal|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=25498678&site=ehost-live|title=Web Site Reviews: The Encyclopedia of Chicago (subscription required)|author=Ethington, Philip J.|accessdate=October 30, 2009|date=June 2007|publisher=[[Journal of American History]]|pages=363–365|volume= 94|issue=1}} ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'' reviewed the ''Encyclopedia'' along with several of its peers and mentioned early in the review that the advent of online encyclopedias makes the works much easier to correct and update. However, the availability of online encyclopedias diminished the significance of the print editions according to the review because it made gifting them less significant and it reduced sales at libraries. The review also noted that the online approach is becoming so successful that the state of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] has produced the online-only ''[[New Georgia Encyclopedia]]'', which started as a 300-article venture and has blossomed to a 1300-article work. However, they noted that when the ''Encyclopedia of Chicago'' was first released that the local media supported the book; some Chicago [[disc jockey]]s read passages from it on air. It enjoyed successful marketing as both a popular gift item and a must-have for local historians.{{cite journal|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=19635677&site=ehost-live|title=Hot Type (subscription required)|accessdate=October 30, 2009|date=February 3, 2006|work=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]|page=A22|author=Howard, Jennifer|volume=52|issue=22}} ==Content== The encyclopedia is composed of 1117 pages that feature over 1400 entries by more than 600 contributors.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CSTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1052A01D20A0ED74&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=It's in The Book // Everything you ever wanted to know about Chicago but didn't know whom to ask . .|accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=September 9, 2004|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|page=16, News section|author=McNamee, Tom}} Additionally, it includes 442 maps, more than 400 vintage photographs,{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:ADHB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=105E66F67056B8CC&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=New book is the word on city, suburban lore From Cracker - Jack to first golf course, Chicago's diverse history linked with - suburbs |accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 6, 2004|work=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]|page=1, News section|author=Pyke, Marni}} over 250 sketches of "historically significant business enterprises",{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1061337D34AA6D03&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Chicago - From 'Abolitionism' To 'Zoroastrians' - An amusing, enlightening--and occasionally frustrating--guide to the city and its environs |accessdate=September 24, 2009|date=October 31, 2004|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=1, Books section|author=Kogan, Rick}} a dictionary of Chicago-area businesses, a biographical dictionary and a 21-page [[timeline]] that traces the history of Chicago from 1630 to 2000. The 1400-entry main alphabetical section of the ''Encyclopedia'' covers all Chicago neighborhoods, suburbs, and ethnic groups as well as the major [[cultural institution]]s. Topics covered include technology and science, architecture, religions, immigration, transportation, business history, labor, music, health and medicine. It is considered the most geographical diverse city encyclopedia of its kind because it fully encompasses the [[suburb]]s in eight of the region's counties. 386 thumbnail maps of neighborhoods and municipalities are complemented by 400 black-and-white photographs plus hundreds of color photographs and thematic maps. There are separate lengthy interpretive essays woven into the alphabetical section on topics such as the built environment, literary images of Chicago, and the city's sports culture. The Encyclopedia includes a 2000-entry comprehensive biographical dictionary and a detailed listing of approximately 250 of the city's historically significant business enterprises. A color insert features a timeline of Chicago history and photo essays exploring nine pivotal years in this history. The photo essays feature the city’s urban art and artifacts. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/ Online edition] *[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0226310159 ''Encyclopedia of Chicago''] at [[Amazon.com]] *[http://blog.chicagohistory.org/index.php/2009/01/encyclopedia-tutorial-1/ ''Encyclopedia of Chicago'' tutorial] at [[Chicago History Museum]] {{Good article}} [[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:English-language encyclopedias]] [[Category:History of Chicago]] [[Category:Northwestern University]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias|Chicago]] [[Category:Encyclopedias of history|Chicago]] [[Category:University of Chicago Press books]]

ݢاݢسن سجهترا
{{nobold|和谐阵线}} | logo = | founded = {{start date|df=yes|2016|3|16}} | ideology = [[Islamic democracy]]{{cite web|url=https://www.themalaysianinsight.com/s/16699/|title=PAS to head third bloc Gagasan Sejahtera|author1=Bede Hong|author2=Radzi Razak|publisher=The Malaysian Insight|date=1 October 2017|accessdate=1 October 2017}}
'''Factions:'''
[[Islamic fundamentalism]]
[[Islamic conservatism]]
[[Social democracy]] | headquarters = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] ([[Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS)|PAS]] & [[Malaysia National Alliance Party|IKATAN]])
[[Pasir Mas]], Malaysia ([[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Front|BERJASA]]) | international = | country = Malaysia | abbreviation = GS/GAGASAN | leader1_title = Leadership | leader1_name = [[Abdul Hadi Awang]]
[[Abdul Kadir Sheikh Fadzir]]
Abdul Kadir Mamat | leader2_title = Secretary-General | leader2_name = Takiyuddin Hassan | slogan = ''Sejahtera Bersama Islam''
''Malaysia Sejahtera'' | predecessor = | successor = | legalised = | dissolution = | newspaper = [[Harakah (newspaper)|Harakah]]
1Media.my | youth_wing = Pemuda Gagasan Sejahtera | think_tank = | membership_year = | membership = | position = [[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] (majority)
[[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] (IKATAN) | colours = {{Color box|{{Gagasan Sejahtera/meta/color}}|border=darkgray}} Green and white | colorcode = {{Gagasan Sejahtera/meta/color}} | anthem = | seats1_title = [[Dewan Negara|Senate]]: | seats1 = {{Composition bar|2|70|hex={{Gagasan Sejahtera/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Dewan Rakyat|House of Representatives]]: | seats2 = {{Composition bar|18|222|hex={{Gagasan Sejahtera/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[Dewan Undangan Negeri|State Legislative Assemblies]]: | seats3 = {{Composition bar|90|587|hex={{Gagasan Sejahtera/meta/color}}}} | website = {{URL|http://gagasansejahtera.my/}} | footnotes = | symbol = [[File:PAS logo.svg|150px]] }} The '''Gagasan Sejahtera''' (English: ''Ideas of Prosperity'', [[abbreviation|abbrev]]: '''GS''') is an informal coalition of opposition [[Islamism|Islamist]] political parties which promote the "ideas of peace" in Malaysia. The coalition was formed initially as a ''Third Force'' on 16 March 2016, consisting of [[Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS)]] and [[Parti Ikatan Bangsa Malaysia]] (IKATAN){{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/03/16/pas-ikatan-seal-formal-third-force-pact/|title=PAS, Ikatan seal 'third force' pact|author=Rahmah Ghazali|publisher=The Star|date=16 March 2016|accessdate=17 March 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/malaysia-s-pas-ikatan-form-new-opposition-alliance-8160532|title=Malaysia's PAS, Ikatan form new opposition alliance|author=Melissa Goh|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=16 March 2016|accessdate=16 March 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2016/03/17/pas-announces-pact-with-ikatan/|title=PAS announces pact with Ikatan|work=Bernama|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=17 March 2016|accessdate=17 March 2016}} and announced that it will be formally called Gagasan Sejahtera on 13 August 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/pas-and-ikatan-form-gagasan-sejahtera|title=PAS and Ikatan To Form Gagasan Sejahtera|author=Syed Jaymal Zahiid|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=13 August 2016|accessdate=13 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://malaysiandigest.com/news/626242-pas-ikatan-pact-to-be-named-gagasan-sejahtera.html|title=PAS-Ikatan Pact To Be Named Gagasan Sejahtera|publisher=Malaysian Digest|date=13 August 2016|accessdate=13 August 2016}} It is a successor to [[Pakatan Rakyat]] (the other being [[Pakatan Harapan]]). [[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Front]] (BERJASA) joined the coalition on 23 September 2016,{{cite web|url=http://www.agendadaily.com/Politik/berjasa-sertai-gagasan-sejahtera-bersama-pas-dan-ikatan.html|title=BERJASA sertai Gagasan Sejahtera bersama PAS dan Ikatan|language=Malay|publisher=Agenda Daily|date=23 September 2016|accessdate=23 September 2016}} The main campaign of the alliance focuses mainly "on PAS political matters and uniting Malay Muslims",{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/pas-malay-muslims-should-be-nations-top-leaders|title=PAS: Malay-Muslims should be nation’s top leaders|author=Syed Jaymal Zahiid|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=19 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.themalaysianinsight.com/s/11462/|title=Dominant Muslim Malays must lead Malaysia, says PAS president|publisher=The Malaysian Insight|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=19 August 2017}} while upholding democracy as the best way to govern the country. The formation of the alliance brought criticism from both the ruling [[Pakatan Harapan]] coalition and the opposition [[Barisan Nasional]].{{cite web|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/pas-trying-fool-third-force-010000186.html|title=Who is PAS trying to fool with ‘third force’ efforts, ask observers|work=The Malaysian Insider|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=12 March 2016|accessdate=23 July 2017}} == Member parties == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" ! rowspan="2"| Flag ! rowspan="2" colspan="4"| Name ! rowspan="2"| Ideology ! rowspan="2"| Leader(s) ! rowspan="2"| Seats

It has representatives in every assembly other than those of [[Negeri Sembilan]], [[Malacca]], [[Sabah]] and [[Sarawak]]. The coalition holds a majority in the [[Kelantan State Legislative Assembly|Kelantan]] and [[Terengganu State Legislative Assembly|Terengganu]] State Legislative Assemblies, and supplies all the members of the state's [[Kelantan State Legislative Assembly#State EXCO|Executive Council]] (a body akin to a [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]]), led by [[List of Menteris Besar of Kelantan|Menteri Besar]], [[Ahmad Yakob]].{{cite web|url=http://www2.nst.com.my/latest/kelantan-announces-state-exco-portfolio-1.275217|title=Kelantan announces state exco portfolio|publisher=New Straits {{italic title}} [[Image:Gai-uron-120764.jpg|right|thumb|260px|Introduction of Gai Luron from an origin panel.<ref name="no1"/>]] '''''Gai-Luron''''' is a [[France|French]] [[comics]] series about a melancholic [[basset hound]], Gai-Luron, created on July 12, 1964 by [[Gotlib]].<ref name="no1">''Gai-Luron ou la joie de vivre'', n°1, p1. Footnote of date of creation by Gotlib</ref> Originally published in the [[Franco-Belgian comics]] magazines ''Vaillant'' and ''[[Pif Gadget]]'', the character joined ''Nanar, Jujube et Piette'', which Gotlib had drawn since 1962, but eventually headlined a hit series of its own.<ref name="lambiek">{{Cite web|last=Lambiek Comiclopedia|title=Gotlib|url=http://lambiek.net/artists/g/gotlib.htm }}</ref> The album collection series began were released from 1975, and the second album, ''Gai-Luron en écrase méchamment'' was awarded the prize for [[Angoulême International Comics Festival Prize for Best Comic Book#1970s|French comical work]] at the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival|Angoulême]] in 1976.<ref name="toutenBD-1976">{{Cite web|last=ToutEnBD|title=Le palmarès 1976|url=http://www.toutenbd.com/article.php3?id_article=848|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313075212/http://www.toutenbd.com/article.php3?id_article=848|archivedate=2007-03-13|df=}}</ref>
==Synopsis== It follows the [[anthropomorphic]] [[dog]] Gai-Luron (whose name can be roughly translated as "Jolly Fellow", which contrasts with Gai-Luron's generally [[apathetic]] behaviour), his girlfriend Belle-Lurette and his friend Jujube the [[fox]].
The plot sometimes involves Gai-Luron and Jujube reading their [[fan mail]], which is almost always written by the same reader, a little boy named Jean-Pierre Liégeois, or else a friend or relative of his.
==Bibliography== Gai-Luron's adventures were published in 10 volumes between 1975 and 1982, and a last one, ''La bataille navale...ou Gai-Luron en slip'', was published as Gotlib's goodbye to the comic strip scene in 1986.
*''Gai-Luron'', collection ''Les Rois du rire'' n°10 (1969, Éditions Vaillant)[[Image:Gailuron.jpg|right]] * 1 : ''Gai-Luron ou la joie de vivre'' (1975, Audie) * 2 : ''Gai-Luron en écrase méchamment'' (1975, Audie) * 3 : ''Gai-Luron rit de se voir beau en ce miroir'' (1976, Audie) * 4 : ''Gai-Luron et Jean-Pierre Liegeois '' (1976, Audie) * 5 : ''Gai-Luron fait rien qu'à copier'' (1977, Audie) * 6 : ''Gai-Luron ce héros au sourire si doux'' (1978, Audie) * 7 : ''Gai-Luron s'en tire par une pirouette'' (1979, Audie) * 8 : ''Gai-Luron drague comme une bête'' (1980, Audie) * 9 : ''Gai-Luron n'engendre pas la mélancolie !'' (1981, Audie) * 10 : ''Gai-Luron tire une tronche pas possible'' (1982, Audie) *''La bataille navale ou Gai-Luron en slip'' (1986, Audie)
==References== {{refbegin}} * [http://bdoubliees.com/vaillantpif/series2/gailuron.htm ''Gai-Luron'' publications in ''Vaillant'' and ''Pif''], and [http://bdoubliees.com/fluideglacial/series2/gailuron.htm ''Fluide Glacial''] BDoubliées {{fr_icon}} * [http://www.bedetheque.com/serie-846-BD-Gai-Luron.html ''Gai Luron'' albums] Bedetheque {{fr_icon}} * [http://www.leconcombre.com/gotlib/gailuron00.html] '''Footnotes''' {{refend}} {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.marcelgotlib.com/ Gotlib official site]

revision.text: In [[computer science]], and in particular [[functional programming]], a '''hylomorphism''' is a [[Recursion (computer science)|recursive]] function, corresponding to the [[function composition|composition]] of an [[anamorphism]] (which first builds a set of results; also known as 'unfolding') followed by a [[catamorphism]] (which then [[fold (higher-order function)|folds]] these results into a final [[return value]]). Fusion of these two recursive computations into a single recursive pattern then avoids building the intermediate data structure. This is an example of [[deforestation (computer science)|deforestation]], a program optimization strategy. A related type of function is a '''metamorphism''', which is a catamorphism followed by an anamorphism. ==Formal definition== A hylomorphism h : A \rightarrow C can be defined in terms of its separate anamorphic and catamorphic parts. The anamorphic part can be defined in terms of a [[arity|unary]] function g : A \rightarrow B \times A defining the list of elements in B by repeated application (''"unfolding"''), and a [[predicate (mathematics)|predicate]] p : A \rightarrow \text{Boolean} providing the terminating condition. The catamorphic part can be defined as a combination of an initial value c \in C for the fold and a binary [[Operation (mathematics)|operator]] \oplus : B \times C \rightarrow C used to perform the fold. Thus a hylomorphism : h\,a = \begin{cases} c & \mbox{if } p\,a \\b \oplus h\,a' \,\,\,where \,(b, a') = g\,a & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases} may be defined (assuming appropriate definitions of p & g). ===Notation=== An abbreviated notation for the above hylomorphism is h = [\![(c, \oplus),(g, p)]\!]. ==Hylomorphisms in practice== ===Lists=== [[List (computing)|Lists]] are common data structures as they naturally reflect linear computational processes. These processes arise in repeated ([[Iteration|iterative]]) function calls. Therefore, it is sometimes necessary to generate a temporary list of intermediate results before reducing this list to a single result. One example of a commonly encountered hylomorphism is the canonical [[factorial]] function. factorial :: Integer -> Integer factorial n | n == 0 = 1 | n > 0 = n * factorial (n - 1) In the previous example (written in [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]], a [[purely functional programming language]]) it can be seen that this function, applied to any given valid input, will generate a linear call tree [[isomorphism|isomorphic]] to a list. For example, given ''n'' = 5 it will produce the following: factorial 5 = 5 * (factorial 4) = 120 factorial 4 = 4 * (factorial 3) = 24 factorial 3 = 3 * (factorial 2) = 6 factorial 2 = 2 * (factorial 1) = 2 factorial 1 = 1 * (factorial 0) = 1 factorial 0 = 1 In this example, the anamorphic part of the process is the generation of the call tree which is isomorphic to the list [1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. The catamorphism, then, is the calculation of the [[product (mathematics)|product]] of the [[element (mathematics)|elements]] of this list. Thus, in the notation given above, the factorial function may be written \text{factorial} = [\![(1,\times),(g, p)]\!] where g\ n = (n, n - 1) and p\ n = (n = 0). ===Trees=== However, the term 'hylomorphism' does not apply solely to functions acting upon isomorphisms of lists. For example, a hylomorphism may also be defined by generating a non-linear call tree which is then collapsed. An example of such a function is the function to generate the ''n''th [[term (mathematics)|term]] of the [[Fibonacci sequence]]. fibonacci :: Integer -> Integer fibonacci n | n == 0 = 0 | n == 1 = 1 | n > 1 = fibonacci (n - 2) + fibonacci (n - 1) [[Image:Fib 4.png|thumb|300px|Call tree for fibonacci 4.]] This function, again applied to any valid input, will generate a call tree which is non-linear. In the example on the right, the call tree generated by applying the fibonacci function to the input 4. This time, the anamorphism is the generation of the call tree isomorphic to the tree with [[leaf node]]s 0, 1, 1, 0, 1 and the catamorphism the [[summation]] of these leaf nodes. ==See also== * [[Morphism]] * Morphisms of [[F-algebra|F-algebras]] ** From an initial algebra to an algebra: [[Catamorphism]] ** From a coalgebra to a final coalgebra: [[Anamorphism]] ** Extension of the idea of catamorphisms: [[Paramorphism]] ** Extension of the idea of anamorphisms: [[Apomorphism]] ==References== * {{cite web |url=http://eprints.eemcs.utwente.nl/7281/01/db-utwente-40501F46.pdf |title=Functional Programming with Bananas, Lenses, Envelopes and Barbed Wire |author1=Erik Meijer |author2=Maarten Fokkinga |author3=Ross Paterson |pages=4, 5 |year=1991 }} ==External links== * [http://ulissesaraujo.wordpress.com/2009/04/09/hylomorphisms-in-haskell/ Hylomorphisms in Haskell] * [http://ulissesaraujo.wordpress.com/2009/04/09/more-hylomorphisms-in-haskell/ More Hylomorphisms in Haskell] [[Category:Articles with example Haskell code]] [[Category:Category theory]] [[Category:Recursion schemes]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=August 2016}} {{Update|date=October 2013}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = iStock by Getty Images | logo = IStock LP 2014 Corporate Logo.png | type = [[Subsidiary]] | genre = [[Microstock photography]] | foundation = {{start date and age|2000|05}} (as iStockphoto) | founder = [[Bruce Livingstone]] | location_city = [[Calgary, Alberta]] | location_country = [[Canada]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = [[Bruce Livingstone]] <small>(founder & CEO)</small> | industry = | products = | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = [[Getty Images]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|iStockphoto.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} {{lowercase|iStockphoto}} '''iStock''' is an online [[royalty free]], [[international]] [[microstock photography|micro stock photography]] provider based in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. The firm offers millions of [[photos]], [[illustrations]], [[clip art]], [[Digital video|video]]s and [[Digital audio|audio]] tracks. Images cost between 1 and 3 credits, with the price of credits ranging from $10.00 to $0.22 depending on volume purchased and subscription plan.<ref>[http://www.istockphoto.com/plans-and-pricing http://www.istockphoto.com/plans-and-pricing] Company pricing page</ref> Artists, [[designers]] and [[photographers]] worldwide contribute their work to iStock collections in return for royalties. Nearly half a million new [[photos]], [[illustrations]], [[video]]s and audio files, are added each month.
== History ==
The company was founded by [[Bruce Livingstone]] in May 2000, as iStockphoto, a free stock imagery website supported by Livingstone's web development firm, Evolvs Media, It began charging money in 2001 and has been profitable since then.<ref name="ST-05-28-07">Kim Peterson, [http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2003724590_istockphoto28.html "Microstock photography represents a new business model"], ''Seattle Times'', May 28, 2007</ref>
On February 9, 2006 the firm was acquired by [[Getty Images]] for $50 million USD. Livingstone promised that the site would continue "functioning independently with the benefits of Getty Images, yet, very importantly for them and us, autonomy. "<ref name=Marketwire>{{cite web|title=iStockphoto Joins Getty Images|url=http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/istockphoto-joins-getty-images-as-explosive-growth-continues-expansion-into-social-media-nyse-gyi-579577.htm|publisher=Marketwire|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref>
On September 18, 2006 the site experienced the first benefits of the new ownership:<ref>[http://www.istockphoto.com/article_view.php?ID=217 istockphoto.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061015170446/http://www.istockphoto.com/article_view.php?ID=217 |date=2006-10-15 }} – Language features announcement</ref> a [[Controlled vocabulary]] keyword taxonomy borrowed from Getty Images.
As of March 31, 2007, [[iStockpro]] closed. iStockpro was a more expensive version of iStockphoto that was never as popular as iStockphoto, and became redundant after the acquisition by Getty Images.
On April 1, 2008 Getty Images disclosed, as part of its agreement to be sold to a private equity firm, that iStockphoto's revenue in 2007 was $71.9 million USD of which $20.9 million (29%) was paid to contributors.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.istockphoto.com/forum_messages.php?threadid=67521 |title=iStock contributors make $21 million in 2007 |publisher=iStockphoto Forums |accessdate=2008-04-01 |date=2008-04-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405183450/http://www.istockphoto.com/forum_messages.php?threadid=67521 |archivedate=2008-04-05 |df= }}</ref>{{citation needed|date=February 2011}}
== Contributors ==
Contributing photographers apply (via a short quiz regarding policies, requirements, basic photographic knowledge, and legal issues) before they are eligible to upload their images. The applicant's sample images are screened for quality and suitability before being approved.
Contributors receive a commission of between 15% and 40% of each sale, depending on whether or not they are "exclusive", and various other factors.
In an address to its community entitled "2008: A Year in Review and a Look Ahead″,<ref>[http://www.istockphoto.com/forum_messages.php?threadid=80935 2008: A Year in Review and a Look Ahead] – Executive Forum Post</ref> the firm's CEO mentioned that the company was paying out ‘almost’ $1.1 million per week in royalty payments to contributors.
== Purchasing and use == Each approved image is added to the searchable online database, where it can be found by purchasers. Files can be downloaded immediately, and used in almost anything. The basic license agreement prohibits some uses, such as [[web templates]], [[print on demand]], adult materials, etc. Print runs over 500,000 must pay additional royalties. Extended licenses are available for purchase to cover needs not met by the basic license agreement.<ref>[http://www.istockphoto.com/license_purchaser.php Extended License Options] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509155246/http://www.istockphoto.com/license_purchaser.php |date=2008-05-09 }}</ref>
== Controversies == [[File:Roommate poster.jpg|thumb|right|This background of a movie poster for the 2011 film ''[[The Roommate]]'' was provided by iStockphoto. The image is that of the Christy Administration building at [[Southwestern College (Kansas)|Southwestern College]]. The college believes this image was used without their permission.]]
===Pricing=== Since iStockphoto's launch in 2000, purchase prices have slowly increased, from initially bartered (based on accumulated contributions),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://istockphoto.com/ |title=iStockphoto.com - The SOURCE for free Royalty Free Stock Photography and Illustration |date=7 April 2000 |publisher= |accessdate=28 October 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000407101943/http://istockphoto.com/ |archivedate=7 April 2000 |df= }}</ref> to $.25 and then $.50,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20030207225936/http://www.istockphoto.com/about2.php web.archive.org] February 7, 2003</ref> and more recently tiered at $1, $2 and $3,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20050510230431/http://istockphoto.com/file_closeup.php?id=142016 web.archive.org] May 10, 2005</ref> to a higher-cost tiered pricing of $1, $3, $5 and $10 or more for extra-high resolution,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060203033452/http://istockphoto.com/index.php web.archive.org] February 3, 2006</ref> to today's current pricing scheme where images cost between 1 and 250 credits, and credits sell for $9 each or from $8 to $5.81 each in bundles of 3 to 3000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.istockphoto.com/plans-and-pricing|title=Download Video and Images: Buy Credits and Subscriptions - iStock|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> Best rates for photos, vectors and illustrations are available through monthly or annual subscriptions.
===Ownership of material=== The 2011 film ''[[The Roommate]]'' obtained photos from iStockPhoto for its promotional material. One of the photos used as its backdrop was the Christy Administration Building from [[Southwestern College (Kansas)|Southwestern College]] in [[Winfield, Kansas]]. The college administration voiced concern that permission to use the photograph of the building was not properly obtained and is investigating the legality of its use.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.winfieldcourier.com/articles/2010/12/03/news/news/doc4cf932cdb33af858348853.txt|publisher = [[The Winfield Daily Courier]]|title = Image of SC building on movie poster|date = December 3, 2010|first = Allen|last = Twitchell|accessdate = January 17, 2011}}</ref> As of February 8, 2011, no lawsuits have been filed but discussions continue to take place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winfieldcourier.com/articles/2011/02/08/news/news/doc4d5183cc7aa41324106218.txt|publisher=[[The Winfield Daily Courier]]|title=Movie poster image remains a concern for SC administration|first=Allen|last=Twitchell|date=February 8, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref>
== iStockvideo == On July 31, 2006 iStockphoto announced the development of a new branch, iStockvideo, to sell stock [[video]] clips in a variety of formats from web-size, through [[NTSC]] and [[PAL]] up to [[HDV]] and [[High-definition video|HD]] sizes. The collection is slated to open on September 5, 2006, and clips (between 5 and 30 seconds) will range in cost from $5 USD to $50 USD, based on resolution. As of February 9, 2010 the video collection contains over 250,000 videos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.istockphoto.com/forum_messages.php?threadid=175161|title=Forums - iStockvideo - 250,000 videos|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> Videos are not available as part of the images pricing or subscription arrangements.
This new branch of iStockphoto competes with motion stock collections already available from companies such as [[Getty Images]], Artbeats, and Veer.
== iStockalypse event == The iStockalypse was founded in 2005, as an official multi-day iStock photography event held several times a year for contributing artists and photographers .<ref>http://www.istockalypse.com/What.aspx</ref>
Since the first event in Las Vegas, iStock has visited [[Seattle]], [[Boston]], [[Ljubljana]], [[Prague]], [[Austin]], [[Barcelona]], [[Marseilles]], [[Buenos Aires]], [[Malta]], [[Berlin]], [[Calgary]], [[Istanbul]], [[Cannes]], [[Tokyo]], [[London]], [[Milan]], [[Singapore]], [[Sao Paulo]], [[Los Angeles]] and [[Paris]]. In March 2015 the event<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.istockalypse.com/CurrentLypse.aspx?lypse_id=11|title=iStockalypse - Dubai|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> was organized in Dubai to get authentic, local shots of the city and its people.
== References == <references/>
== External links == *{{Official website|http://www.istockphoto.com}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Treaty | name = Independence of Singapore Agreement 1965 | long_name = ●[[s:Agreement relating to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia as an independent and sovereign state|Agreement relating to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia as an independent and sovereign state]]
●[[s:Agreement relating to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia as an independent and sovereign state/Annex A|Proclamation on Singapore]]
●[[s:Agreement relating to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia as an independent and sovereign state/Annex B|Constitution and Malaysia (Singapore Amendment) Act, 1965]] | image = Agreement relating to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia as an independent and sovereign State.djvu | image_width = 250px | caption = Independence of Singapore Agreement 1965 | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 7 August 1965 | location_signed = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] | date_sealed = | date_effective = 9 August 1965 | condition_effective = | signatories = Government of [[Malaysia]]
Government of [[Singapore]] | parties = {{flag|Malaysia}}
{{flag|Singapore}} | depositor = [[Singapore]] Government
dated 1 June 1966
The [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|Secretary-General]] of the {{flag|United Nations}} acting in his capacity as depositary the following:''See'': [[United Nations General Assembly Resolution 97 (1)]]
[http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%20563/volume-563-I-8206-English.pdf English] and [http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%20563/volume-563-I-8206-French.pdf French]
[http://treaties.un.org/pages/showDetails.aspx?objid=080000028012b8be Registered No. I-8206] | language = [[English language|English]] | languages = | wikisource = Agreement relating to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia as an independent and sovereign state }} {{Formation of Malaysia}} The '''Independence of Singapore Agreement 1965''' was an [[Treaty|agreement]] between the Government of [[Malaysia]] and the Government of [[Singapore]] on 7 August 1965 that granted [[independence]] to Singapore. The Singapore Act 1966 followed the treaty.[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1966/29/pdfs/ukpga_19660029_en.pdf Singapore Act 1966] The agreement included a Proclamation on Singapore to be made by Malaysian Prime Minister [[Tunku Abdul Rahman]]; a different [[Proclamation of Singapore]] was made by Singapore prime minister [[Lee Kuan Yew]]. As a result of the agreement, Singapore achieved full independence from Malaysia with effect from 9 August 1965. ==See also== * [[Malaysia Agreement]] was signed on 9 July 1963 at [[London]] * [[Malaysia Act 1963]] * [[Singapore Act 1966]] * [[United Nations General Assembly Resolution 1514 (XV)]] * [[Succession of states]] * [[Vienna Convention on Succession of States in respect of Treaties]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Independence of Singapore Agreement 1965}} [[Category:Formation of Malaysia]] [[Category:History of Malaysia]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Malaysia]] [[Category:1965 in Malaysia]] [[Category:1965 in Singapore]] [[Category:Malaysia–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Singapore–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Legal documents]] [[Category:Malaysian monarchy]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1965]] [[Category:Treaties entered into force in 1965]] [[Category:Treaties of Malaysia]] [[Category:Treaties of Singapore]] [[Category:Treaties involving territorial changes]] {{statute-stub}}

In [[mathematics]] and particularly in [[dynamic systems]], an '''initial condition''',<ref>{{cite book |last=Baumol |first=William J. |authorlink=William Baumol |title=Economic Dynamics : An Introduction |location=London |publisher=Collier-Macmillan |edition=3rd |year=1970 |isbn=0-02-306660-1 }}</ref>{{rp|pp.160}} in some contexts called a '''seed value''', is a value of an evolving variable at some point in time designated as the initial time (typically denoted ''t'' = 0). For a system of [[order (differential equation)|order]] ''k'' (the number of time lags in [[discrete time]], or the order of the largest derivative in [[continuous time]]) and [[dimension (vector space)|dimension]] ''n'' (that is, with ''n'' different evolving variables, which together can be denoted by an ''n''-dimensional [[coordinate vector]]), generally ''nk'' initial conditions are needed in order to trace the system's variables forward through time.
In both [[differential equation]]s in continuous time and [[difference equation]]s in discrete time, initial conditions affect the value of the dynamic variables ([[state variable]]s) at any future time. In continuous time, the problem of finding a [[closed form solution]] for the state variables as a function of time and of the initial conditions is called the [[initial value problem]]. A corresponding problem exists for discrete time situations. While a closed form solution is not always possible to obtain, future values of a discrete time system can be found by iterating forward one time period per iteration, though rounding error may make this impractical over long horizons.
==Linear system==
===Discrete time===
A linear [[matrix difference equation]] of the homogeneous (having no constant term) form <math>X_{t+1}=AX_t</math> has closed form solution <math>X_t=A^tX_0</math> predicated on the vector <math>X_0</math> of initial conditions on the individual variables that are stacked into the vector; <math>X_0</math> is called the vector of initial conditions or simply the initial condition, and contains ''nk'' pieces of information, ''n'' being the dimension of the vector ''X'' and ''k'' = 1 being the number of time lags in the system. The initial conditions in this linear system do not affect the qualitative nature of the future behavior of the state variable ''X''; that behavior is [[stability (mathematics)|stable]] or unstable based on the [[eigenvalue]]s of the matrix ''A'' but not based on the initial conditions.
Alternatively, a dynamic process in a single variable ''x'' having multiple time lags is
:<math>x_t=a_1x_{t-1} +a_2x_{t-2}+\cdots +a_kx_{t-k}.</math>
Here the dimension is ''n'' = 1 and the order is ''k'', so the necessary number of initial conditions to trace the system through time, either iteratively or via closed form solution, is ''nk'' = ''k''. Again the initial conditions do not affect the qualitative nature of the variable's long-term evolution. The solution of this equation is found by using its [[Eigenvalues and eigenvectors#Dynamic equations|characteristic equation]] <math>\lambda^k-a_1\lambda^{k-1} -a_2\lambda^{k-2}-\cdots -a_{k-1}\lambda-a_k=0</math> to obtain the latter's ''k'' solutions, which are the [[characteristic value]]s <math>\lambda_1, \dots , \lambda_k,</math> for use in the solution equation
:<math>x_t=c_1\lambda _1^t+\cdots + c_k\lambda _k^t.</math>
Here the constants <math>c_1, \dots , c_k</math> are found by solving a system of ''k'' different equations based on this equation, each using one of ''k'' different values of ''t'' for which the specific initial condition <math>x_t</math> Is known.
===Continuous time===
A differential equation system of the first order with ''n'' variables stacked in a vector ''X'' is
:<math>\frac{dX}{dt}=AX.</math>
Its behavior through time can be traced with a closed form solution conditional on an initial condition vector <math>X_0</math>. The number of required initial pieces of information is the dimension ''n'' of the system times the order ''k'' = 1 of the system, or ''n''. The initial conditions do not affect the qualitative behavior (stable or unstable) of the system.
A single ''k''<sup>th</sup> order linear equation in a single variable ''x'' is
:<math>\frac{d^{k}x}{dt^k}+a_{k-1}\frac{d^{k-1}x}{dt^{k-1}}+\cdots +a_1\frac{dx}{dt} +a_0x=0.</math>
Here the number of initial conditions necessary for obtaining a closed form solution is the dimension ''n'' = 1 times the order ''k'', or simply ''k''. In this case the ''k'' initial pieces of information will typically not be different values of the variable ''x'' at different points in time, but rather the values of ''x'' and its first ''k'' – 1 derivatives, all at some point in time such as time zero. The initial conditions do not affect the qualitative nature of the system's behavior. The [[Characteristic equation (of difference equation)|characteristic equation]] of this dynamic equation is <math>\lambda^k+a_{k-1}\lambda^{k-1}+\cdots +a_1\lambda +a_0=0,</math> whose solutions are the [[Eigenvalues and eigenvectors|characteristic value]]s <math>\lambda_1,\dots , \lambda_k;</math> these are used in the solution equation
:<math>x(t)=c_1e^{\lambda_1t}+\cdots + c_ke^{\lambda_kt}.</math>
This equation and its first ''k'' – 1derivatives form a system of ''k'' equations that can be solved for the ''k'' parameters <math>c_1, \dots , c_k,</math> given the known initial conditions on ''x'' and its ''k'' – 1 derivatives' values at some time ''t''.
==Nonlinear systems==
[[Nonlinear system]]s can exhibit a substantially richer variety of behavior than linear systems can. In particular, the initial conditions can affect whether the system diverges to infinity or whether it [[convergence (mathematics)|converges]] to one or another [[attractor]] of the system. Each attractor, a (possibly disconnected) region of values that some dynamic paths approach but never leave, has a (possibly disconnected) [[basin of attraction]] such that state variables with initial conditions in that basin (and nowhere else) will evolve toward that attractor. Even nearby initial conditions could be in basins of attraction of different attractors (see for example [[Newton's method#Basins of attraction]]).
Moreover, in those nonlinear systems showing [[chaos theory|chaotic behavior]], the evolution of the variables exhibits [[sensitive dependence on initial conditions]]: the iterated values of any two very nearby points on the same [[strange attractor]], while each remaining on the attractor, will diverge from each other over time. Thus even on a single attractor the precise values of the initial conditions make a substantial difference for the future positions of the iterates. This feature makes accurate [[Simulation#Computer simulation|simulation]] of future values difficult, and impossible over long horizons, because stating the initial conditions with exact precision is seldom possible and because rounding error is inevitable after even only a few iterations from an exact initial condition.
==See also==
*[[Initialization vector]], in cryptography

{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = John Tolos |names = John Tolos
Coach{{cite web|title=Wrestler Profiles: John Tolos|work=Online World of Wrestling|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/j/john-tolos.html|accessdate=2008-05-05}}
Golden Greek |image = John_Tolos.jpg |image_size = |caption = |height = {{height|ft=6|in=2}}{{cite book|title=WWE Encyclopedia|last1=Shields|first1=Brian|last2=Sullivan|first2=Kevin|page=160|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley|DK]]|year=2009|isbn=978-0-7566-4190-0}} |weight = {{convert|240|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |real_height = |real_weight = |death_cause = [[Kidney failure]] |birth_date = September 18, 1930 |birth_place = [[Hamilton, Ontario]], Canada{{cite web|last=Oliver|first=Greg|title="The Golden Greek" John Tolos dies|work=[[Canadian Online Explorer|SLAM! Wrestling]]|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2009/05/29/9616266.html|accessdate=2009-05-29}} |death_date = {{death date and age|2009|5|29|1930|9|18}} |death_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]],
[[United States]] |billed = |trainer = Willie Davis |debut = |retired = |website = }} '''John Tolos''', [[nickname]]d '''"The Golden Greek"''', (September 18, 1930 – May 28, 2009) was a [[Greeks|Greek]]-[[Canadians|Canadian]] [[professional wrestler]], and [[professional wrestling manager]]. ==Professional wrestling career== John was born on September 18, 1930 in Hamilton, Ontario to [[Greeks|Greek]] parents, Nicolaos and Evangelia (Evangeline) Tolos. During the 1950s and 60s, Tolos was part of the Canadian Wrecking Crew with his brother [[Chris Tolos]]. On December 28, 1963, John and Chris captured the [[WWWF United States Tag Team Championship]] in [[Teaneck, New Jersey]] in two straight falls from [[Gorilla Monsoon]] and [[Killer Kowalski]]. While both teams were heels at the time, the Tolos Brothers did a television interview prior to the title match, "looking forward" to seeing all of their fans in Teaneck. That night, they were cheered throughout. As a vicious heel known as the "Golden Greek", Tolos also engaged in a long time rivalry with [[Freddie Blassie|"Classy" Freddie Blassie]] in the [[Gene LeBell|LeBell]] family's [[List of NWA territories|Los Angeles territory]], often feuding over the [[NWA Americas Heavyweight Championship|Americas Championship]]."Classy" Freddie Blassie with Keith Elliot Greenberg, ''Listen, You Pencil Neck Geeks'', (WWE Books, 2003). Tolos joined the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) for a brief stint in mid-1991 as Coach (a classic [[coach (sport)|coach]], whistle and all), managing [[Beverly Brothers|The Beverly Brothers]] and [[Curt Hennig|"Mr. Perfect" Curt Hennig]], replacing Hennig's former manager [[Bobby Heenan|Bobby "The Brain" Heenan]], who was then moving into a full-time broadcaster's role.{{cite book|title=WWE Encyclopedia|last1=Shields|first1=Brian|last2=Sullivan|first2=Kevin|page=65|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley|DK]]|year=2009|isbn=978-0-7566-4190-0}} When a back injury sidelined Hennig for more than a year, Tolos was replaced by [[Lanny Poffo|The Genius]] as The Beverly Brothers' manager and departed the WWF. Tolos then had a run in Herb Abrams' [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Herb Abrams)|Universal Wrestling Federation]], managing [[Bob Orton, Jr.|Cowboy Bob Orton]], [[Mick Foley|Cactus Jack]] and The Power Twins as well as serving as color commentator on the UWF's ''Fury Hour'' program. ==Death== Tolos died in [[Los Angeles, California]] on May 29, 2009. His death was from [[kidney failure]] [http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-john-tolos1-2009jun01,0,5561561.story John Tolos dies at 78; notorious wrestling villain known as the Golden Greek] - ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Retrieved on 2009-06-02. following a series of [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]s and [[stroke]]s. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[50th State Big Time Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Hawaii Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA Hawaii Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/hi/hi-h.html|title=NWA Hawaii Heavyweight Title|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=December 29, 2012}} **[[NWA Pacific International Championship|NWA North American Heavyweight Championship ''(Hawaii version)'']] ([[NWA Pacific International Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/hi/nwa/hi-us-h.html|title=NWA United States Heavyweight Title (Hawaii)|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29}} **[[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) - with [[Stephen Cepello|Steve Strong]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/hi/hi-t.html|title=Hawaii Tag Team Title|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29}} *'''[[Big Time Wrestling (Detroit)|Big Time Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Detroit version)|NWA World Tag Team Championship ''(Detroit version)'']] ([[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Detroit version)#Title history|1 time]]) - with Chris Tolos{{cite web|title=NWA World Tag Team Title (Detroit)|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/mi/nwa/mi-nwa-t.html}} *'''California Pro Wrestling''' **CPW Heavyweight Championship (1 time){{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2000|edition=4th | isbn=0-9698161-5-4 }} *'''[[Cauliflower Alley Club]]''' **Golden Potato Award (2004) *'''[[Championship Wrestling from Florida]]''' **[[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Florida version)|NWA World Tag Team Championship ''(Florida version)'']] ([[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Florida version)#Title history|1 time]]) - with Tony Borne (2), Chris Tolos (2), Black Terror (1), [[Dutch Savage]] (1), and [[Don Leo Jonathan]] (1){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/bc/nwa/bc-can-t.html|title=NWA Canadian Tag Team Title (Vancouver)|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2008-02-25}} **[[NWA Pacific Coast Heavyweight Championship (Vancouver version)|NWA Pacific Coast Heavyweight Championship ''(Vancouver version)'']] ([[NWA Pacific Coast (Vancouver) Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|title=NWA Pacific Coast Heavyweight Title|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2008-02-25|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/bc/nwa/bc-pc-h.html}} **[[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Vancouver version)|NWA World Tag Team Championship ''(Vancouver version)'']] ([[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Vancouver version)#History|3 times]]) - with Great Kojika (2), Louie Tillet (1), Rock Riddle (1), [[Chavo Guerrero, Sr.|Chavo Guerrero]] (1), and [[Jody Hamilton|The Assassin]] (1){{cite web|title=NWA Americas Tag Team Title|work=Wrestling Titles|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/hw/ams-t.html|accessdate=2008-02-25}} **[[NWA "Beat the Champ" Television Championship]] ([[NWA "Beat the Champ" Television Championship#title history|4 times]]){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/hw/ams-tv.html|title=Beat the Champ Television Title (Los Angeles)|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29}} **NWA Brass Knuckles Championship ''(Los Angeles version)'' (3 times){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/hw/la-bk.html|title=Brass Knuckles Title (Los Angeles)|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29}} **[[NWA United National Championship]] ([[NWA United National Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|url=http://wrestling-titles.com/japan/alljapan/un.html|title=NWA United National Heavyweight Title|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29}} *'''[[NWA Los Angeles]]''' **[[WWA International Television Tag Team Championship|NWA International Television Tag Team Championship]] ([[WWA International Television Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with [[Gene Kiniski]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/nwa/int-tv-t.html|title=International Television Tag Team Title (Los Angeles)|work=Wrestling Titles|accessdate=2009-05-29}} *'''[[NWA San Francisco]]''' **NWA Pacific Coast Tag Team Championship ''(San Francisco version)'' (1 time) -
